item.title: Report E-2024050654
item.description:
Report E-2024050654

Identified by scraper @ 2024-05-30T18:16:39+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-24
  • City: SALT LAKE CITY
  • State: UT
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 11000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal USU experienced a UN1791 12.5% Sodium Hypochlorite release from a 300-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 25-gallons of product released to a 10’ x 15’ area of the concrete dock floor. The cap came off the tote after the container fell off the pallet due to improper loading. The material was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. Absorbents were deployed to clean the impacted area. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with all impacted absorbents into (3) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2024050414
item.description:
Report E-2024050414

Identified by scraper @ 2024-05-24T15:13:39+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-13
  • City: W VALLEY CITY
  • State: UT
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 3000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On May 13, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of corrosive liquid was punctured by a nail in transit and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from EnviroServe (ES) to remediate the impacted site. ES personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted trailer and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum. The damaged 55-gallon drum of product was placed into one (1) 95-gallon drum.
